Jeffrey,

I have been able to get python to give me the information I need 
about each individual grid point.  However, I can't figure out how to 
get python to correctly import a previously calculated solution to 
use as the initial guess for the next run.  I only know how to do 
this in Matlab, and it is important so that I can vary parameters 
like mdot on each run without the next solution taking too long.  Do 
you know the correct syntax needed to import solutions into python?  
Thank you very much for your help.

Jeff Miller

Colorado School of Mines Engineering




--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Bergthorson, Jeffrey M." 
<jeffb@t...> wrote:
> Jeff,
> 
> To obtain thermal conductivities or other gas properties, you need 
to
> define some functions in the matlab or python script that defines 
your
> problem.  In my stagnation-point flame simulations, I added the
> following commands to StagnationFlow.py:
> 
>     def density(self, point):
>     	self.setGasState(point)
>     	return self.gas.density()
>     	
>     def viscosity(self, point):
>       self.setGasState(point)
>     	return self.gas.viscosity()
>     	
>     def thermalConductivity(self, point):
>       self.setGasState(point)
>     	return self.gas.thermalConductivity()
> 
>     def meanMolarMass(self, point):
>       self.setGasState(point)
>     	return self.gas.meanMolarMass()
> 
> I then created a file write.py that can be called to write the 
output to
> comma-delimited files.
> 
> def csvwrite(filename,f,gas):
> 	z = f.flow.grid()
> 	T = f.T()
> 	u = f.u()	
> 	V = f.V()
> 	fcsv = open(filename+'.csv','w')
> 	writeCSV(fcsv, ['z (m)', 'u (m/s)', 'V (1/s)', 'T 
(K)', 'density
> [kg/m^3]', 'Mean Mol. Mass [kg/kmol]', 'viscosity 
[Ns/m^2]', 'Thermal
> Cond. [W/m/K]'] + list(gas.speciesNames()))
> 	for n in range(f.flow.nPoints()):
>     		f.setGasState(n)
>     		writeCSV(fcsv, [z[n], u[n], V[n],
> T[n],f.density(n),f.meanMolarMass(n),f.viscosity
(n),f.thermalConductivit
> y(n)]+list(gas.moleFractions()))
> 	fcsv.close() 
> 
> This contains a loop that sets the gas properties to that 
corresponding
> to each solution point.  These values are then written to file.
> 
> You should be able to do something very similar in your burner-flame
> script in Matlab.
> 
> Hope that helps,
> 
> Jeffrey M. Bergthorson
> Postdoctoral Scholar in Aeronautics
> California Institute of Technology
> Pasadena, CA, 91106
> 626.395.4445 (phone)
>  
> -----Original Message-----
> From: cantera@yahoogroups.com [mailto:cantera@yahoogroups.com] On 
Behalf
> Of Jeff Miller
> Sent: Tuesday, September 27, 2005 9:38 PM
> To: cantera@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [cantera] Flame 1
> 
> I am using flame1.m in Matlab to calculate the stand off distance 
for a
> burner flame.  I need to know the thermal conductivity at each grid
> point.  The command, thermalConductivity(gas) returns the thermal
> conductivity of the gas at the final grid point.  The command, 
solution
> (fl, 'flow', thermalConductivity(gas)) returns a list containing the
> correct number of entries, but they are not even close to the 
correct
> values (the first point is 500, and most of the rest are 0).  My
> ultimate goal is to write a csv file containing the velocity,
> temperature, and thermal conductivity profiles.  This is easy on 
Python,
> but I still have not figured out how to import solutions into 
python to
> use as an initial guess.  Does anyone know how to get the thermal
> conductivity at each grid point in Matlab, or how to import 
solutions as
> initial guesses in Python?  
> 
> Thank you very much for any help you can offer.
> 
> Jeff Miller
> 
> Colorado School of Mines Engineering
> 
>
